meanings.definition: To separate or divide into parts
meanings.sent1: I will dispart the puzzle pieces to make it easier for you to solve.
meanings.sent2: She used a knife to dispart the sandwich into halves.
meanings.sent3: The magician will dispart the rope into two pieces and then magically join them back together.
meanings.sent4: His speech seemed to dispart the crowd, leaving some in agreement and others in disagreement.
meanings.sent5: The river disparted the forest, creating two distinct habitats for different animals.

meanings.definition: To cause to be separate or distinct
meanings.sent1: The new policy will dispart the company into two separate entities.
meanings.sent2: His actions will dispart the friends, causing a rift in their relationship.
meanings.sent3: The chef's unique recipe will dispart this dish from all others on the menu.
meanings.sent4: The artist's use of color disparted the painting, making each element stand out.
meanings.sent5: The mountain range disparted the two neighboring countries, creating a natural border.

meanings.definition: To shoot or fire a gun or cannon
meanings.sent1: The soldier will dispart at the enemy troops to defend the fort.
meanings.sent2: He disparted at the target with precision during the shooting competition.
meanings.sent3: The cowboy disparted at the cans lined up on the fence for target practice.
meanings.sent4: The hunter disparted at the deer, aiming for a clean shot.
meanings.sent5: The police officer disparted a warning shot to disperse the crowd peacefully.

meanings.definition: A shot or discharge from a gun or cannon
meanings.sent1: The loud dispart echoed through the valley, signaling the start of the battle.
meanings.sent2: The old cannon displayed a historic dispart from the Civil War era.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected dispart startled the birds perched on the tree branches.
meanings.sent4: The powerful dispart from the artillery shook the ground beneath our feet.
meanings.sent5: The distant dispart of fireworks lit up the night sky in celebration.
